Book By Dr. Painter

The occasion for the founding of
the club is the recent publication of
"William Marshal, Knight-Errant,
Baron, and Regent of England" by
Dr. Sidney Painter. The volume is
the first of the Johns Hopkins Historical Publications.
It goes into details about the career of William Marshall as a typical nobleman of the period. The
importance of the work lies in the
fact that it supplies an essential need
in presenting an aspect of the time
which is closed to the ordinary history text and possible only in biography.

Imperialist Exploitation

The only two places in the world
today in which there is room for
imperialist and financial expansion,
according to Geiser, are South
America and China. "It is no accident that war happens to be existing in these two places today," he
said, asserting that in both places
there are potential markets for the
imperialist nations to exploit.
Warning the audience that the reforestration project is not what it is
supposed to be, Geiser advised that
it may be connected with American
war preparations.
A senior at Fenn College, Geiser
was president of the student council, editor of the college weekly, and
head of the honorary society there
until his withdrawal from school in
February.

Book By Dr. Painter

The occasion for the founding of
the club is the recent publication of
"William Marshal, Knight-Errant,
Baron, and Regent of England" by
Dr. Sidney Painter. The volume is
the first of the Johns Hopkins Historical Publications.
It goes into details about the career of William Marshall as a typical nobleman of the period. The
importance of the work lies in the
fact that it supplies an essential need
in presenting an aspect of the time
which is closed to the ordinary history text and possible only in biography.

Imperialist Exploitation

The only two places in the world
today in which there is room for
imperialist and financial expansion,
according to Geiser, are South
America and China. "It is no accident that war happens to be existing in these two places today," he
said, asserting that in both places
there are potential markets for the
imperialist nations to exploit.
Warning the audience that the reforestration project is not what it is
supposed to be, Geiser advised that
it may be connected with American
war preparations.
A senior at Fenn College, Geiser
was president of the student council, editor of the college weekly, and
head of the honorary society there
until his withdrawal from school in
February.
